content.description: Starts on flakes on the face around the corner from the V5 and follow the holds to the top. Mantle.
Start matched on the glued/chipped flakes and make the big moves up through long reaches and small crimps to reach the final moves. Mantle.
content.location: Larger boulder located near the Tram parking lot, just down and left from trail kiosk.

content.description: Start both hands on orange crimps, paste your feet on and throw to lip. Mantle. Good quality rock, but sharp.
content.location: Begins on the face opposite The Corner, in front of the tree.

content.description: Start matched on the incut sidepull, paste your feet on and make big moves to establish on the triangle flake and continue up and finish same as for Scrapula.

One of the more classic boulder problems of the grade in the Sandias. Font style climbing in the foothills. Start on the rounded triangle flake at chest level and make the long reaches up the rounded corner eventually reaching the top. Mantle.
content.location: Head south on any one of the developed trails and veer towards the  egg shaped boulder that sits by itself.

content.description:
A rare steep problem on perfect edges and crimps. Start left hand on a good crimp, right hand on the good rail, make the long, first move to get establish on the long rail. Crux comes establishing on the two crimps high on the prow and generating momentum to get around the arete to reach better holds. 

  Another sequence could possibly make the finish easier by a grade, but risks a potentially sketchy fall onto uneven, downhill sloping, terrain.  

  A direct finish also looks possible, albeit quite intimidating as well.
content.location: A nice little jaunt from the parking lot at the Tram via the service road. Once you arrive at the first blue service tower, head north about 100 meters up hill. The boulder problem faces south.

content.description: Another Tram area classic. Start low on the arete and work up and right through cool holds and tenuous slab moves to top out. This problem is harder that it looks.
content.location: From Acrobatics, continue going south east on the well traveled trail.

content.description: Start low on the arete matched on a good flake and make the hard, painful moves up the prow on sharp crimps to the top. Mantle.
content.location: Located on the hillside south east of mixed arete.

content.description: Tall slab on an exposed perch. Thin near the top.
content.location: (35.1977665,-106.4770873)Follow the tramway trail north from the tram a while until you see a smaller trail breaking off eastward toward a canyon. The trail heads upward, eventually dropping into a wash at the mouth of the canyon. A small scramble up and to the left of the canyon entrance leads to the base of the slab.

content.description: Same start as Acrobatics, but with a slightly harder finish going up and right, using the round corner.
Located in the middle of the wall just left of Mini G. Start on decent crimps, smear feet and make the hard throw to the sloping lip. Mantle.

(I'm not entirely sure of the name) Starts on the face directly behind Mixed Arete.  Begins on a low right facing flake and moves up and right through bad crimps (some of which may have broken since I did it) to a big throw over the lip to a crack. Mantle.

Start on two horizontal crimps with a high right toe hook about 10 feet left of the start of "Knife Club".  Work your way right and out of the corridor through a cool ledge feature and a decent matchable rail into the start of "Knife Club".  Finish up the thin and high tension V11.
content.location: The lower/left start to "Knife Club". Back in the corridor formed by the "Mixed Arete" boulder.

content.description: Short problem with excellent holds and fun sequence. Start down in the pit.
content.location: (35.1984106,-106.4817633)Right off the trail on the other side of the wash.

content.description: Start low on the arete and make the powerful reaches up the green arete to top. Mantle.
content.location: Short, steep, lichen covered arete. South of Mixed Arete area.

content.description: Steep, aesthetic crimp problem leading to a throw to an excellent lip feature before the top out. This would clean up nicely with more traffic, as there are a lot of suspect crimps one must avoid when working out the problem.
content.protection: pads. spotter would help avoid fall into cholla near the base

content.description: Highball slab problem. The first two thirds are more technical slab moves. The final third eases considerably, which is great because a fall from up there would be bad.
content.location: (35.1991613,-106.4811220)In the corridor and on the side opposite of "everybody rides the carousel"

content.description: Fun overhanging crimp problem. Can climb right- or left-of-center; the latter is slightly more difficult.
content.location: Approximate coordinates: (35.1980147,-106.4800132).Head north for awhile on the tramway trail from the tram, then bushwhack uphill/east for a few minutes.

content.description: Right of srapula, start on cool pocket feature, plaster feet and make big left hand move to sloper gaston and press up to foot hand match
content.location: Right of scrapula. The scrapula boulder is 100' north of Timy's chipped v9

content.description:
Just before the you reach the parking lot of the tram, turn left on Sandia Heights, then turn right at the stop sign and follow the road until you see the House Boulder on your right. This is the best place to park for the Tram area, unless you want to pay the $1 to park in the parking lot.  

  Be aware that the boulder is basically split by a property line designated by a small piece of rebar (barely) visible near the bottom left corner of the photo. The left side of the boulder lies on the property line and should probably not be climbed on, The Corner however, appears to be okay.  

  Right hand start on pinch, left hand on incut crimp, climb up following holds to big move just below the lip. Mantle.   

  More than likely needs to be cleaned as it has been a while since this line has seen some action.
Starting low squeezing the arete, make difficult slaps up to a good hold just below the lip. Control the swing. Mantle.
Short, but fun compression arete sequence. If only it were longer...
This might be the most famous of all foothills boulder problems, as it appeared in a French climbing magazine some time back.
content.location: From the House Boulder, head South East and cross through the drainage. Acrobatics starts at the base of the mini-dihedral and moves up and left through pinches and crimps. Aptly named for it's gymnastic style and need for flexibility.

content.description: More granite blocks surrounding the area about the base of the Tram. Some of the rock is exceptional and a handful of really nice problems such as Scrapula V6. The majority of the problems are to the east and north of the Tram terminal and pretty dispersed.
